awd_titl_txt: Conference: 12th International Conference on Biomolecular Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will make it possible for 13 graduate students and 6 early career faculty to attend the 12th International Conference on Biomolecular Engineering (ICBE) to be held in Santa Barbara, CA on January 8-11, 2023. Biomolecular engineering utilizes powerful and versatile tools for advancing science and engineering in applications ranging from the design of new biocatalysts to directing microbiomes to identify and destroy viral and microbial pathogens. The ICBE conference series was initiated in 2007 to foster interaction among academic, national laboratory, and industrial molecular researchers developing and applying molecular engineering methods. This conference will feature 24 plenary speakers, three keynote speakers, and a poster session. With no parallel sessions, the meeting structure is designed to encourage interaction between established and early career researchers and promote mentoring of the latter. Also, the selection of invited speakers represents a high level of diversity. 

The organizing theme of the conference is the question: How can biomolecular engineering address grand challenges in healthcare, energy and the environment?  Biomolecular engineering provides the potential to revolutionize many different industries and positively impact of society. For example, advances in biomolecular engineering are aimed at developing more efficient and sustainable methods of producing food, fuels, and chemicals. In the medical field, biomolecular engineering has led to the development of new drugs, diagnostic tests, and therapies that can help treat and cure diseases. Additionally, biomolecular engineering has the potential to help address global challenges such as climate change and the need for clean energy. The Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (ENG/CBET), and the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences (BIO/MCB) contributed funds to this award.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The 12th International Conference on Biomolecular Engineering (ICBE) took place Januar 8-11. 2023 in Santa Barbara, California. The Conference Chairs were Katie Galloway, MIT and Aditya Kunjapur, University of Delaware. Throughout the four days of the conference, events featured keynotes, technical presentations, poster presentations and networking events. ICBE accomplished its goal of gathering researchers who are using quanititative approahes to advance the understanding and application of molecular biology to stimulate discussion and integrate approaches across the scales of biological complexity.

ICBE gathered 60 attendees, primarily early career researchers, students and post-docs at U.S. academic institutions. The conference provided early career faculty with one of their first opportunities to give an oral presentation and participate in a leadership role helping to plan the event. These opportunities are important for attendees' career development, receiving feedback on research, establishing themselves in the community and helping to develop their networks for future collaborations.

Keynote Speakers Included:

  • Wilfred Chen, University of Delaware
  • Michelle O'Malley, University of California, Santa Barbara
  • Mikhail Shapiro, Caltech

Session Topics Included:

  • Emerging Technologies in Molecular Engineering
  • Cellular Engineering
  • Biomolecular Engineering for Human Health
  • Protein Engineering
  • Biomolecular Engineering for Environmental Health
  • Biomolecular Engineering to Advance Fundamental Science

The grant from the National Science Foundation allowed many of the early career faculty members to participate in the conference. As Assistant Professors are establishing their labs, they often don't have excees funds to participate in a conference and take advantage of the career development opportunities mentioned above. The NSF grant eased these burdens for many attendees, supporting a total of 30 early career faculty, graduate students and post-docs.

The next ICBE will take place in January, 2025. The meeting will continue to focus on similar topics and aims to grow to 100-125 attendees as in-person events continue to recover coming out of Covid.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/07/2024
Modified by: Evan Flach
